unnormalised: Healthcare records are increasingly going digital, and with it, we're seeing numbers pop up everywhere. From your hospital registration no. to your blood test results, it's all about digits these days. Take Priya Sharma, for instance. Her medical record shows a BMI of 28.5 and a blood pressure reading of 130/85. These numbers tell doctors a lot about her health status. It's a major shift from the old days of handwritten notes.
normalised: Healthcare records are increasingly going digital, and with it, we're seeing numbers pop up everywhere. From your hospital registration number to your blood test results, it's all about digits these days. Take Priya Sharma, for instance. Her medical record shows a B-M-I of twenty eight point five and a blood pressure reading of one hundred and thirty divided by eighty five. These numbers tell doctors a lot about her health status. It's a major shift from the old days of handwritten notes.

unnormalised: Think about a typical visit to a clinic in Delhi. First, you’ll probably get a token number, say 27. Then, the doc will check your vitals. Maybe your temperature is 99.5°F or your heart rate is 72 bpm. Post consultation you may have to pay a bill of Rs. 1500, which is generated in a system and duly noted in your digital record. These numbers, big or small, are critical for tracking patient health.
normalised: Think about a typical visit to a clinic in Delhi. First, you’ll probably get a token number, say twenty seven. Then, the doc will check your vitals. Maybe your temperature is ninety nine point five degree Fahrenheit or your heart rate is seventy two B-P-M. Post consultation you may have to pay a bill of rupees one thousand five hundred, which is generated in a system and duly noted in your digital record. These numbers, big or small, are critical for tracking patient health.

unnormalised: Lab reports are another treasure trove of numbers. A complete blood count (CBC) report might show hemoglobin levels at 12.0 g/dL and platelet count at 250,000/μL. A lipid profile could reveal cholesterol at 220 mg/dL. These figures help diagnose conditions and monitor treatment effectiveness. Even the dosage of medication, like taking 500mg of Paracetamol, is all about numbers. It is a really integral part of the healthcare system.
normalised: Lab reports are another treasure trove of numbers. A complete blood count (C-B-C) report might show hemoglobin levels at twelve point zero gram per deciliter and platelet count at two hundred and fifty thousand per microliter. A lipid profile could reveal cholesterol at two hundred and twenty milligram per deciliter. These figures help diagnose conditions and monitor treatment effectiveness. Even the dosage of medication, like taking five hundred milligram of Paracetamol, is all about numbers. It is a really integral part of the healthcare system.

unnormalised: Then there are appointment reminders. "Your appointment with Dr. Kumar is scheduled for 15/11/2024 at 10:30 AM," your phone buzzes. Numbers again, guiding us through the healthcare journey. Hospitals also track bed occupancy rates, say 85%, and patient satisfaction scores, which might average at 4.2 out of 5. It's like a numerical heartbeat of the institution.
normalised: Then there are appointment reminders. "Your appointment with Doctor Kumar is scheduled for fifteenth November two thousand and twenty four at ten thirty A-M," your phone buzzes. Numbers again, guiding us through the healthcare journey. Hospitals also track bed occupancy rates, say eighty five percent, and patient satisfaction scores, which might average at four point two out of five. It's like a numerical heartbeat of the institution.

unnormalised: But with all these numbers, data privacy becomes a big concern. We’re talking about sensitive info like Aadhaar no. linked to medical records. The data is mostly kept secure nowadays. Regulations are tightening up and also evolving with new technology. It helps in improving the security.
normalised: But with all these numbers, data privacy becomes a big concern. We’re talking about sensitive info like Aadhaar number linked to medical records. The data is mostly kept secure nowadays. Regulations are tightening up and also evolving with new technology. It helps in improving the security.

unnormalised: So, from registration to diagnosis to treatment, numbers are an inseparable part of modern healthcare. They streamline processes, provide insights, and ultimately, improve patient care. As tech advances, we can expect even more sophisticated numerical analysis to play a role in keeping us healthy. And that’s something we can all count on.
normalised: So, from registration to diagnosis to treatment, numbers are an inseparable part of modern healthcare. They streamline processes, provide insights, and ultimately, improve patient care. As tech advances, we can expect even more sophisticated numerical analysis to play a role in keeping us healthy. And that’s something we can all count on.
